title: 104_s845
content: The Act titled "Supplemental Social Security Income Flexibility Act of 1995" introduces block grants to states for Supplemental Security Income for the disabled and blind under Title XVI of the Social Security Act. The purpose of the "Supplemental Social Security Income Flexibility Act of 1995" is to consolidate Federal assistance to States for supplemental income for disabled or blind individuals into a single grant, allowing States flexibility to enforce requirements such as school attendance, immunizations, drug restrictions, and denying assistance based on inability to perform age-appropriate activities. The "Supplemental Social Security Income Flexibility Act of 1995" allows States to deny assistance to individuals with disabilities due to drug or alcohol abuse, illegal aliens, and requires sponsors of legal aliens to support them. It also involves various private sector organizations in providing assistance to needy disabled and blind individuals. "Payments to states for assistance under the Supplemental Social Security Income Flexibility Act of 1995." "Each State is entitled to receive quarterly payments for fiscal years 1997-2000, amounting to 25 percent of the annual amount determined under paragraph (2) for carrying out the purpose described in section 1651. The annual amount is based on previous funding received by the State in fiscal years 1992-1994 under part A of this title for disabled or blind individuals." The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to each State based on previous funding received for disabled or blind individuals. States must expend the funds within the fiscal year or set aside amounts for a rainy day fund. The State can set aside funds for unexpected increases in assistance for disabled or blind individuals. States cannot use the funds for medical services, but can use up to 30% for other purposes. The State can set aside funds for unexpected increases in assistance for disabled or blind individuals, up to 30% for other purposes. Any amount paid to the State under this part for a fiscal year to carry out a State program under specific provisions of law is not subject to the requirements of this part, but to the requirements of the law providing the funds. "administrative and fiscal accountability" The State must conduct annual audits of expenditures from funds received under this part to ensure compliance with regulations. Audits must be performed by an approved entity following accepted auditing principles. The State must conduct annual audits of expenditures from funds received under this part to ensure compliance with regulations. Audits must be performed by an approved independent entity and submitted to the State legislature and the Secretary of the Treasury within 30 days. States must repay any amounts not expended in accordance with regulations plus a 10% penalty. The State must conduct annual audits of expenditures from funds received under this part to ensure compliance with regulations. Audits must be performed by an approved independent entity and submitted to the State legislature and the Secretary of the Treasury within 30 days. States must repay any amounts not expended in accordance with regulations plus a 10% penalty. Additional accounting requirements apply, and States are required to prepare comprehensive annual reports on activities carried out with the received amounts, following generally accepted accounting principles. The State must prepare comprehensive annual reports on activities funded under this part, following accepted accounting principles. Reports must include the most recent audit results and necessary information to accurately describe activities and expenditures. Copies of these reports must be made available for public inspection. The State must prepare annual reports on activities funded under this part, following accounting principles. The Secretary of the Treasury supervises the funds received, making payments to States and approving entities. The Secretary of the Treasury supervises the funds received by States under this part, with limited federal oversight. No other federal department or agency can issue regulations regarding the purpose of this part. The curr_chunk states "nondiscrimination provisions" in the context of limited federal oversight by the Secretary of the Treasury over funds received by States under this part. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination based on disability, sex, race, color, or national origin in programs funded under this part. Compliance is monitored by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury shall notify the State's chief executive officer to secure compliance with anti-discrimination laws within 60 days. If compliance is not achieved, the Secretary may refer the matter to the Attorney General, utilize powers under various civil rights acts, or take other legal actions. The Attorney General may bring civil actions in district court for relief, including injunctive relief, when a matter is referred or if there is reason to believe an entity is violating the law. The Attorney General can take legal action in district court, including seeking injunctive relief, if there are concerns about entities violating the law, such as nondiscrimination and institutional protections for religious providers. Religious organizations can provide assistance to disabled or blind individuals funded under this part without compromising their religious character or freedom. They shall not be discriminated against based on their religious mission or purpose. Religious organizations receiving assistance funded under this part can maintain their independence from government control over their religious beliefs and practices. They have the right to hire, promote, and dismiss individuals based on religion, but cannot deny benefits to disabled or blind individuals on religious grounds. Religious providers of assistance funded under this part are not required to change their internal governance or facilities, including religious symbols, to be eligible for assistance. They must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations similar to other providers. Religious organizations receiving federal funds under this part must follow auditing principles and may segregate funds for separate accounts. They can take legal action if their rights are violated. Beneficiaries of assistance have rights as well. Each State must provide a certificate to beneficiaries who object to receiving assistance from a religious organization, allowing them to redeem it with another provider. Cash cannot be given in exchange for these certificates. Section 1602 of the Social Security Act is amended to restrict eligibility for disabled or blind individuals under certain conditions after September 30, 1996. Eligibility for services funded under part C of the title is still available. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include block grants to States for supplemental security income for disabled individuals. These amendments will take effect on October 1, 1996.
